author: Bud Shaw, Northeast Ohio Media Group
title: Browns need to send Johnny Manziel a strong message Sports Spin
text:
CLEVELAND, Ohio â€“ Browns GM Ray Farmer says the Browns "take seriously" an incident involving Johnny Manziel and his girlfriend that ended up in an Avon police report this week first reported by newsnet5.com.
How seriously?
Hopefully, more seriously than last year when they too often brushed off his behavior after he made news with his social media posts and nightlife excursions.
They said then they weren't going to micromanage players away from Berea.
Now's the time to change that.
When it comes to Manziel, micromanage away.
Manziel spent much of his offseason in a treatment program, which is an obvious backdrop for an incident this week in which the Browns quarterback and his girlfriend admitted they were drinking .
Without that stay, they could dismiss this as things that happen between couples and say, well, it was his off day.
You can read the details and decide for yourself if it's a red flag for Manziel personally. It should be. How could it not? His well-being is what's most important.
Next to that, No. 2 on the list is what the Browns decide to do next. Let him practice? He did practice this week.
Cut him? It's a sensitive situation given that he sought help for an undefined addiction problem less than a year ago.
But deactivating him for Sunday is a reasonable middle ground.
There's a reason why it made sense the Browns returned to Josh McCown after a concussion against the Jets knocked him out of the game. Maybe we know even more now.
Manziel played three quarters of that game and struggled in a 31-10 loss. He was limited against Tennessee by his own coaching staff and the circumstances of the game but made a late great throw to seal the 28-14 win.
The drum beat for him to start and to put McCown out to pasture was predictable, I guess. But it belied what Manziel dealt with over the offseason and what he consistently produced on the field in training camp and in the Tennessee game.
The coaching staff showed no hesitation in returning McCown to the huddle. McCown has shown why.
Maybe Manziel did, too, this week.
The Browns should by now know what Manziel's issues are and how he's dealing with them. They should know the fact from the rumors that didn't go away this summer.
They hinted at no disciplinary measures in the Farmer statement.
We'll see come Sunday. They've made a statement with their reluctance to rely on him in favor of a 36-year old quarterback coming off a 1-10 season.
Sunday, with McCown an injury away from being sidelined, they get another chance.
